title: October Revolution Island
text:
October Revolution Island (Russian: Остров Октябрьской Революции, "Ostrov Oktyabrskoy Revolyutsii") is the largest island of the <a href="Severnaya%20Zemlya">Severnaya Zemlya</a> group in the <a href="Russia">Russia</a>n <a href="Arctic">Arctic</a>. It is named after the <a href="October%20Revolution">October Revolution</a> which led to <a href="Russia">Russia</a> becoming a <a href="Communism">communist</a> country.
The area of this island has been estimated at making it the <a href="List%20of%20islands%20by%20area">59th largest island in the world</a>. It rises to a height of on <a href="Mount%20Karpinsky%2C%20October%20Revolution%20Island">Mount Karpinsky</a>. Half the island is covered with <a href="glacier">glacier</a>s reaching down into the sea. In the sections free from ice, the vegetation is <a href="desert">desert</a> or <a href="tundra">tundra</a>.
Geography.
October Revolution Island houses five domed <a href="ice%20cap">ice cap</a>s; clockwise from north, they are named: <a href="Rusanov%20Glacier">Rusanov</a>, <a href="Karpinsky%20Glacier">Karpinsky</a>, <a href="University%20Glacier">University</a>, <a href="Vavilov%20Glacier">Vavilov</a> and <a href="Albanov%20Glacier">Albanov</a>. The Rusanov and Karpinsky ice caps, located on the eastern side of the island, feed with glaciers the <a href="Matusevich%20Fjord">Matusevich Fjord</a> of the <a href="Laptev%20Sea">Laptev Sea</a> and the <a href="Marat%20Fjord">Marat Fjord</a> of the <a href="Shokalsky%20Strait">Shokalsky Strait</a>. The Karpinsky ice cap reaches a maximum height of 963 m and it is also the highest point in Severnaya Zemlya.
In 2015 the Vavilov Glacier accelerated dramatically due to warming. Between 2015 and 2016 the glacier front advanced 4 km and the glacier lost 4.5 km3 of ice.
Other minor ice caps on the island include the <a href="Malyutka%20Glacier">Malyutka Glacier</a>. The Podemnaya River and the Bolshaya River drain to the northwest between the Vavilov and <a href="Valerian%20Albanov">Albanov</a> glaciers, and the Bedovaya and Obryvistaya Rivers drain to the north between the Albanov and <a href="Vladimir%20Rusanov">Rusanov</a> ice caps.
The coast of the island is uneven with rugged coves and headlands. The largest bays of the island are along the northern coast. The <a href="Red%20Army%20Strait">Red Army Strait</a> separates October Revolution Island from Komsomolets Island to the north and from <a href="Pioneer%20Island%20%28Russia%29">Pioneer Island</a> in the northwest, while the broader <a href="Shokalsky%20Strait">Shokalsky Strait</a> separates it from Bolshevik Island to the south. Both straits connect the Kara Sea in the west with the Laptev Sea in the east. <a href="Cape%20October">Cape October</a> is located in the northern part of the island facing the Red Army Strait.
History.
The island was discovered by <a href="Boris%20Vilkitsky">Boris Vilkitsky</a> in 1913 during an expedition on behalf of the <a href="Russian%20Hydrographic%20Service">Russian Hydrographic Service</a>, but its insularity was not proven until 1931, when <a href="Georgy%20Ushakov">Georgy Ushakov</a> and <a href="Nikolay%20Urvantsev">Nikolay Urvantsev</a> charted the archipelago during their 1930–1932 expedition.
The <a href="Sergey%20Ivanovich%20Vavilov">Vavilov</a> Meteorological Station was operated from 1974 to 1988 on the northern part of the Vavilov Ice Cap.
